content.description: This route follows 3 bolts up an inside corner, to a roof use the face on the right for big holds, then step left and under the roof to the anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a pair of rap rings
content.location: the obvious inside corner at the far right end of the Lower Slabs

content.description: Vertical fracture line. 3rd line in from the left facing corner. Lots of small edges. left facing edge is crux after bolt 2.
content.protection: 3 bolts to shared rings with Welcome Direct
content.location: Lower Climbs (reservoir level)

content.description: 3 bolts to shared rings with Welcome to safe harbor. 2nd route in from the left facing corner. Crux is at 2nd bolt.
content.location: Lower Climbs (reservoir level)

content.description:
A chunky section with big holds and good feet lead up from the left to a jug by the first bolt. Pull past the jug to a slab with large comfortable diagonal cracks for hands and feet, then romp to the top. 

  This has to be the easiest climb on the lower slabs. Super easy and pleasant climbing, no more than 5.3. 

  A fantastic easy climb, it still feels like climbing even though it's very easy. Do it!
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location: Left side of the Lower Climbs, the climb just left of the 11a.

content.description: Easy climb to the right of Sunless in Seattle.
content.location: Lower Climbs (reservoir level) just to the right of a concrete block below the 'pseudo' climbs.

content.description: 3 bolts, anchors with rings
content.protection: always wear protection especially when your making truffle butter.
content.location: climbers left of Pseudo Slab and climber right of I'm Lichen it.

content.description: Easy blocky climb. Might harder than a 5.7, probably a 5.8. A bit of a run out to the anchors on 5.5 climbing. Nice climb, thoughtful moves through the bulge.
content.location: Lower Climbs (reservoir level) just to the right of a concrete block below the 'pseudo' climbs.

content.description: Start on a steep and slick slab and climb the overhanging face on positive holds past 2 bolts.
content.location: 2nd route on the left hand side of the Lower Slabs.

content.description: Climbed everything else at the quarry and need something to do on a hot summer day? Solo up vienna lager to the last bolt. Clip that and sling the horn to the left and build an anchor. Bring up your second, then embark into the sea of bolts on the right. pull the crux of blind faith and then stay at about that elevation through some nice moves and comfy holds. it gets a little spicy towards the end as you have sort of a run out climbing through the crux of mighty midget, The second faces quite the fall if they blow it. Semi hanging belay at the Mighty Midget anchors. Easy when no one else is at the wall but logistically more challenging, and more fun, when the walls full of other climbers, clipping their hung draws as you go, well as long as you know them first.
Blocky bouldery start, move to the left leaning diagonal that leads up toward the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, shares big beefy anchor bolts with Pseudo Slab
content.location: Lower Climbs (Reservoir Level)

content.description: Enough good edges to get up. Avoid knocking the dirt and rocks up top and along the vein 1/2 way up.
content.protection: A few bolts, shared anchor bolts (no rings) with Pseudo Slab Right
content.location: Lower Climbs (reservoir level) This is in the broken area between the flatter slab/clean faces. Start on a Concrete Block

content.description: Start on the concrete block, the crux is the first couple of moves going off the block, with small feet, and bad hands, after the climbing eases off.
content.location: The rightmost line that starts on the concrete block on the lower slabs.

content.description: The route follows 3 bolts through blocky overhanging jugs to the chains
content.location: Located on the far right hand side of the Lower Slabs

content.description: Fun slab route, have to look for holds. Worth repeating.
This climb goes up the flat face.
content.location: 2 routes to the left of the obvious vertical fracture that is Welcome to Safe Harbor

content.description: This is no longer the 5.6 it used to be. A key hold broke, making this a 5.8 or so. Actually, I thought the bottom (where the hold broke) was still really easy. Tricky little move up the slab on top.
content.protection: 4 bolts, plus a 2-bolt anchor.  The first bolt is very low, almost reachable from the ground.
content.location: Lower climbs (reservoir level) - this is the third climb from the left.  Look for the low first bolt.

content.description: Follow the bolts up a slabby line left of a tree.
content.location: Middle of the Lower Climbs.

content.description: Climb up some easy 5th, crux comes pulling through a bulge and some balancy moves around the 4th bolt.
content.location: First route on the Lower Slabs

content.description: Start on sloping holds and continue up past 3 bolts.  Utilizing a sharp crimp  at bolt #3 and pulling up to the positive holds on the flake is the crux.  A few easy moves put you at the chains.
content.location: The rightmost route on the gravel ledge past Mighty Midget.

content.description: A low angle climb with large holds. Obvious black lichen trough climb just right of the flat clean slab.
content.protection: A couple bolts, it's own anchor
content.location: Lower Climbs (reservoir level)

content.description: Start climbing in the corner that eventually turns into an overlap/small roof, pull the roof (the far right crimp is very loose) and tackle the slab, the hand holds and feet are very small making the top quite tenuous.
content.location: First route on the left hand side behind the concrete block.

content.description: Easy climbing (don't forget to stem) to the third bolt, pull one hard move and follow jugs to the anchors.
content.location: Belgian Blonde and Evil Twin start on a gravel ledge right of Mighty Midget.

content.description: Another short face slab climb typical of this section of the Bird', which isn't as featureless as it looks on closer examination. A tricky little slab, gets pretty blank between the last bolt and the anchors

Lower Climbs in Birdsboro Quarry. This is a popular place to warm up on the shortest, lowest section of Birdsboro. Most of the routes of slabby and of moderate difficulty. The short height of the wall makes it easy to communicate and instruct newer leaders at cleaning and rappelling.
